description: From Middle English sere, from Old French cire, from Latin cera (“wax, cere”), or via Latin cero (“I smear or coat with wax”).

entries.meaning: (ornithology) A fleshy, waxy area at the base of the upper beak in certain birds.

verbs.description: cere (third-person singular simple present ceres, present participle cering, simple past and past participle cered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To wax; to cover or close with wax.
